title: 112_s2016
content: The "Fresh Regional Eating for Schools and Health Act of 2011" includes provisions for increasing access to healthy food for families through programs like the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program and promoting local foods. It also aims to support small and new farmers by providing loans for agricultural producers. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to ensure that food purchased with supplemental nutrition assistance program benefits will increase nutritional value and help beneficiaries meet Federal nutrition guidelines. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to require states applying for waivers to solicit public input for at least 90 days to develop innovative projects for agricultural producers, SNAP beneficiaries, anti-hunger advocates, and public health groups. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to include reporting requirements for retail food stores with annual gross sales over $1,000,000 participating in the supplemental nutrition assistance program. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 now includes reporting requirements for retail food stores with annual gross sales over $1,000,000 participating in the supplemental nutrition assistance program. Individuals who use benefits under this program must submit a report listing any food purchased during the previous calendar year, which will be compiled by the Secretary and submitted to Congress within 90 days. SEC. 102. SMARTPHONE AND TABLET TECHNOLOGY; QUALIFIED ONLINE RETAILERS. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to include recommendations for the use of smartphone and tablet technology in accepting electronic benefit transfers under the supplemental nutrition assistance program. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to include recommendations for implementing smartphone and tablet technology for accepting electronic benefit transfers under the supplemental nutrition assistance program in each State. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to include recommendations for implementing smartphone and tablet technology for accepting electronic benefit transfers under the supplemental nutrition assistance program in each State. The Secretary shall issue recommendations to State agencies on the use and implementation of smartphone and tablet technology for electronic benefit transfers within 90 days of enactment, and each State agency must ensure implementation within 180 days as a condition of participation in the program. State agencies must ensure that prime contractors responsible for electronic benefit transfer services implement smartphone and tablet technology for accepting electronic benefit transfers. Additionally, online food retailers meeting specific requirements can now participate in the program. Online food retailers meeting specific requirements can now participate in the program, with the exception that benefits from the supplemental nutrition assistance program cannot be used to pay for delivery fees. SEC. 103. LOCAL FOODS. Section 6 of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to allocate 50 percent of funds for agricultural commodities and foods to schools participating in food service programs. The amendment allows schools in food service programs to purchase local foods directly. If the purchase negatively impacts specialty crops, schools may be required to use funds to buy local specialty crops. SEC. 104 amends the Child Nutrition Act to allow retail stores to receive alternate forms of training for WIC program. (a) Direct Farm Ownership Loans amended to include individuals with a baccalaureate degree related to farm management. Suspension of limitations on eligibility period for direct farm ownership loans. (b) Eligibility of Food Banks and Nonprofit Hunger Assistance Organizations for Operating Loans amended. The Farm and Rural Development Act is amended to include food banks and nonprofit hunger assistance organizations. The limitation on the period for which borrowers are eligible for direct operating loans is suspended, and the Microloan program is introduced. The Farm and Rural Development Act is amended to include food banks and nonprofit hunger assistance organizations. A new Microloan program is established within the operating loan program, with loan amounts ranging from $500 to $5,000 and a 30-day processing timeline for applications. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to expedite loan applications and reduce paperwork requirements. The limitation on the period for which borrowers are eligible for guaranteed assistance is suspended.
